subject: Geography
note: Content vehicles for KS3 Geography. Seeded from Topics layer + v4 teacher feedback (Adeyemi). Each case study includes contrasting pairs where applicable.

vehicles.name: Haiti 2010 Earthquake
vehicles.description: Case study of the 2010 Haiti earthquake — tectonic causes, impacts on a developing country, and the effectiveness of international response.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain the tectonic CAUSE of the earthquake and why Haiti was particularly VULNERABLE (linking physical and human factors)? Can they evaluate the effectiveness of international response using data? Can they compare Haiti's experience with a contrasting HIC case study?
success_criteria: Explain the tectonic cause of the Haiti earthquake
Analyse why Haiti was particularly vulnerable (physical + human factors)
Evaluate the effectiveness of international aid using data
Compare impacts and responses with a contrasting HIC earthquake

vehicles.name: Japan 2011 Earthquake and Tsunami
vehicles.description: Contrasting case study — the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami in Japan, a HIC with advanced preparedness. Contrasts with Haiti to explore how development affects disaster outcomes.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain why Japan experienced both earthquake AND tsunami (subduction zone mechanics)? Can they compare Japan's preparedness and outcomes with Haiti's? Can they evaluate whether technology makes countries 'safe' from tectonic hazards?
success_criteria: Explain the tectonic cause including subduction and tsunami generation
Compare Japan's preparedness and outcomes with Haiti's
Evaluate the role of technology in hazard management
Explain what 'cascading hazard' means using the Fukushima example

vehicles.name: Climate Change: Causes, Evidence and Mitigation
vehicles.description: Global climate change — greenhouse effect, evidence from ice cores and temperature records, impacts on different regions, and mitigation vs adaptation strategies.
vehicles.location: Global (with regional case studies: Arctic, Bangladesh, Sahel)
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain the greenhouse effect and how human activity enhances it? Can they use climate data (graphs, maps) to identify trends and patterns? Can they evaluate why climate change impacts are unequal and assess the fairness of mitigation strategies?
success_criteria: Explain the enhanced greenhouse effect with scientific accuracy
Use climate data to identify trends and draw conclusions
Explain why climate change impacts are geographically unequal
Evaluate mitigation vs adaptation strategies for different countries

vehicles.name: Development and Global Inequality: Nigeria
vehicles.description: Nigeria as a case study for development and global inequality — economic growth, oil wealth, regional disparities, and the limitations of GDP as a development measure.
vehicles.location: Nigeria (with comparisons to UK and other African nations)
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils use multiple development indicators to build a nuanced picture of Nigeria? Can they explain why GDP alone is an inadequate measure of development? Can they analyse the 'resource curse' concept and evaluate whether oil has helped or hindered Nigeria's development?
success_criteria: Use multiple indicators (GDP, HDI, literacy) to describe Nigeria's development
Explain the limitations of single development indicators
Analyse regional inequalities within Nigeria using data
Evaluate whether oil wealth has helped or hindered Nigeria's development

vehicles.name: Urbanisation: Lagos and London
vehicles.description: Contrasting urbanisation case study — megacity growth in Lagos (LIC) vs managed growth in London (HIC). Covers push-pull factors, challenges, and sustainable solutions.
data_points: London: average house price 15x median salary
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain WHY Lagos is growing rapidly (push-pull factors)? Can they compare the challenges facing Lagos and London, linking to development level? Can they evaluate sustainable urban solutions for both cities?
success_criteria: Explain push-pull factors driving urbanisation in Lagos
Compare challenges in Lagos and London using data
Evaluate the effectiveness of urban management strategies
Explain the concept of sustainable urban development with examples

vehicles.name: Resource Management: UK Water
vehicles.description: Resource management case study — UK water supply and demand, the north-south divide, water transfer schemes, and sustainable management.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain WHY there is a water surplus in the north and deficit in the south? Can they evaluate the costs and benefits of water transfer schemes? Can they compare UK water management with a water-scarce country?
success_criteria: Explain the causes of UK water supply-demand imbalance
Use maps and data to describe the distribution of water surplus and deficit
Evaluate at least 2 strategies for managing water supply
Compare UK water issues with a contrasting country

vehicles.name: Africa: Place Depth Study
vehicles.description: In-depth study of Africa — challenging stereotypes through diverse case studies covering physical landscapes, cultural diversity, economic development, and urbanisation.
vehicles.location: Africa (multiple countries: Kenya, Morocco, South Africa, Ethiopia)
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils challenge stereotypes about Africa using specific evidence from diverse countries? Can they explain the physical geography that shapes different African environments? Can they analyse development patterns across the continent?
success_criteria: Challenge at least 2 common stereotypes about Africa with evidence
Describe the physical geography of at least 2 contrasting African environments
Explain factors affecting development in specific African countries
Use data to compare development indicators across African nations

vehicles.name: Asia: Place Depth Study
vehicles.description: In-depth study of Asia — from the Himalayas to megacities, covering physical processes, population, economic growth, and environmental challenges.
vehicles.location: Asia (multiple countries: China, India, Japan, Bangladesh)
data_points: China and India = 36% of world GDP
Bangladesh: 170 million in area smaller than Iowa
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how physical geography shapes human activity in Asia (e.g. monsoon farming, Himalayan hazards, delta flooding)? Can they evaluate the costs and benefits of rapid economic growth? Can they compare development in contrasting Asian countries?
success_criteria: Explain how physical geography shapes human activity in 2 Asian locations
Evaluate the costs and benefits of rapid economic growth in China or India
Compare development indicators across contrasting Asian countries
Analyse how population pressure creates both challenges and opportunities

vehicles.name: Geographical Fieldwork Investigation
vehicles.description: Fieldwork investigation — pupils design and carry out geographical enquiry, collecting primary data, using GIS, and presenting findings. Applicable to any local environment.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils design a geographical enquiry with a clear question and methodology? Can they collect, present, and analyse primary data? Can they use GIS to enhance their investigation? Can they evaluate the reliability of their findings?
success_criteria: Design a geographical enquiry with a clear question and methodology
Collect primary data using appropriate techniques
Present data using maps, graphs, and GIS where appropriate
Analyse findings and evaluate the reliability of conclusions

vehicles.name: Middle East: Place Depth Study
vehicles.description: In-depth study of the Middle East — oil economies, conflict, cultural heritage, water scarcity, and rapid modernisation.
data_points: Region holds 48% of proven oil reserves
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain how oil wealth has shaped development in the region? Can they analyse why water scarcity is a critical issue? Can they evaluate how conflict and resources are interconnected?
success_criteria: Explain how oil wealth has shaped contrasting development paths in the region
Analyse the causes and consequences of water scarcity
Evaluate the relationship between resources and conflict
Compare development in contrasting Middle Eastern countries using data
